Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Climate and Topographic Controls on Little Ice Age Glacial Advances

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation project investigates the climate and topographic controls on glacial advances during a period known as the Little Ice Age (LIA, approximately AD 1300 to 1850). Glaciers provide a critical freshwater supply in arid and semi-arid areas around the world, so understanding the dynamics of glaciers is of societal importance. Glacial advances and retreats are strongly affected by climate change, but are also influenced by local topographic and glaciological factors. These factors then can either reinforce or dampen the effects of changes in temperature and moisture. This project will constrain the formation ages of the landforms left behind by the LIA glacial advances to test whether the LIA glacial advances are asynchronous across a mountain region. Then, detailed mapping of the LIA and modern glacier extents from Google Earth imagery will be used to evaluate the relationship between the magnitude of the LIA glacial advances and local topographic and glaciological factors. Understanding the spatial and temporal pattern of the LIA glacial advances will provide significant insights into the shifting dominance of different atmospheric systems and their interplay with local topographic and glaciological factors. This knowledge is of critical importance for climate models to predict future climate scenarios. In particular, the detailed study from the sites selected in the Central Asian highlands will provide an understanding of relationships between the westerlies and the Siberian High, and possibly the Asian monsoon, in driving glacial advances and retreats over complex mountainous landscapes.

This project will fill a gap in knowledge of the timing and extent of the LIA glacial advances and provide well-constrained, paleo-climate information to help better understand future climate and environmental changes. The glacial maps delineated based on high-resolution Google Earth imagery will provide an updated glacier inventory to document the status of glacier changes. In addition to the support for this doctoral dissertation research, this project will provide training for an undergraduate student in geologic dating and paleo-climate reconstruction. Research results of this project will be disseminated to a variety of audiences through conference presentations, journal publications, and scientific outreach by integrating the research content into foreign language (Chinese) classes in local K-12 schools and the Confucius Institute at the University of Tennessee. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Yanan Li has completed her dissertation research “Timing and Extent of the Little Ice Age (LIA) Glacial Advances in the Eastern Tian Shan, China” under the support of the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. During her funding period from 2013 to 2015, she collected cosmogenic nuclide samples, conducted laboratory work, learned GIS and statistical skills in data analysis, and accumulated knowledge on glacial geomorphology and chronology. Her research filled a gap in knowledge of the timing and extent of the LIA glacial advances and produced a well-constrained record of glacial changes during and since the LIA in the eastern Tian Shan, a major mountain range in Central Asia.

Yanan Li has accomplished the goal of her research and achieved intellectual merits of valuable findings. Reconstructing past glacial dynamics is of importance to understand how glaciers had responded to climate change. Her study focused on the LIA, a cold period occurred 200–700 years ago when glaciers advanced in many regions of the world. As the retreat of glaciers has been accelerated in recent decades, it is important to know how much glaciers have shrunk in the past a few hundreds of years and what factors contributed to different magnitudes of the retreat. To determine when the glaciers advanced during the LIA, Yanan Li applied cosmogenic nuclide dating technique to constrain the exposure ages of the presumed LIA glacial landforms. Dating results constrained three major LIA advances around 730 years, 370 years, and 210 years ago in the eastern Tian Shan. Dating results also revealed that the timing of the maximum LIA advance is different in different mountain ranges, likely reflecting the impact of different climate and topographic settings. With the advantage of high-resolution satellite imagery available in Google Earth, this project also conducted the geomorphic mapping the presumed LIA glacial extents in correspondence to 865 modern glaciers in the eastern Tian Shan. The mapping results indicate that these glaciers have lost 38.8% of their LIA maximum extents till 2006–2010, and glaciers in the western part lost more than the eastern part of the eastern Tian Shan. GIS and statistical analyses also revealed that the size, elevation, and slope of the glacier are the three most significant local factors to affect the magnitude of glacial retreat in addition to the impact from the climate change.

Yanan Li’s work had much broader impacts beyond academia and was disseminated to audience of interest and in public. As glaciers contribute considerably to the freshwater supply in the populated dry areas in Central Asia, glacier and its associated environmental changes may have significant impact on water availability and water security in this rapidly developing region with multiple bordered countries, and studying glacier change during the past centuries is essential to better predict future glacial and environmental changes. The findings of this research have been presented through professional conferences and invited talks, and published in academic journals during the grant period. The science within this project has been brought to general audience through outreach activities, such as guest talks at local middle schools, lab tours for visitors, campus display during Geography Awareness Weeks, and presentations at National Geographic workshop. Local residents were involved and got to know the importance of this research when conducting fieldworks. An undergraduate student was hired to assist Google Earth mapping and learned how to interpret landforms using satellite imagery.

This dissertation work enables better understanding of how glaciers have changed in the past centuries in a key region over the world. It is an important contribution to the development of science and technology studies.
